review.title: A Comparison of Non-stationary, Type-2 and Dual Surface Fuzzy Control
review.abstract: Type-1 fuzzy logic has frequently been used in control systems. However this method is sometimes shown to be too restrictive and unable to adapt in the presence of uncertainty. In this paper we compare type-1 fuzzy control with several other fuzzy approaches under a range of uncertain conditions. Interval type-2 and non-stationary fuzzy controllers are compared, along with 'dual surface' type-2 control, named due to utilising both the lower and upper values produced from standard interval type-2 systems. We tune a type-1 controller, then derive the membership functions and footprints of uncertainty from the type-1 system and evaluate them using a simulated autonomous sailing problem with varying amounts of environmental uncertainty. We show that while these more sophisticated controllers can produce better performance than the type-1 controller, this is not guaranteed and that selection of Footprint of Uncertainty (FOU) size has a large effect on this relative performance.

sections.heading: B. Tuning & Optimisation
sections.text: While the manual adjustment of the original member functions ([14] and [15]) was performed, we did not perform specific automatic adjustments for two main reasons. First, to ensure universality, and this would not be possible if we were using a specific training data set. Second, it would be difficult to ensure that the same amount of tuning was performed for any other type of fuzzy, as the adjustment requires different methods, such as a type 1 system compared to a type 2, which could potentially lead to unfair comparisons.

sections.heading: C. Tacking Behaviours
sections.text: A disadvantage of using SASP to test these controllers is the limitations of the wind - no boat can sail directly into the wind. To solve this problem, a higher control has been added, which changes the desired direction to the controller. In order to sail into the wind, a turning behavior is required in practice. The design of the courses for our experiments attempts to minimize this effect by setting courses that are designed to avoid the need for turning. The mainsail on the boat is controlled by a simple set of rules that was previously developed in collaboration with the PI controller and has proven to be acceptable.

sections.heading: III . EXPERIMENTAL SETUP
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: A. Tracksail
sections.text: The tracksail simulator used in this research has previously been used for the development and testing of autonomous sailing robotic systems [16], including the development and tuning of the described PI controller. Tracksail is based on Java and communicates with controllers via a TCP / IP socket, which allows any compatible language to be used to control the boat. Each controller is integrated into a common framework that, in addition to any other common code required, provides tactile logic, sensor measurements and motor change routines, ensuring consistency between runs with different controllers. One goal of this work is to investigate changes in the performance of type 2 controllers as the size of the FOU varies. This is facilitated by the simulator by eliminating many categories of uncertainty that are not directly relevant to this investigation, including sensor noise, where the value returned by the sensor does not really reflect the physical value, for example, it measures.

sections.heading: B. Track Configuration
sections.text: Each experiment consists of 30 simulator runs, in which the tested controller attempts to guide the boat to a single waypoint defined as 550 meters west of its starting point, defined by the simulator as a point (0.0). In the first experiment, the wind direction was set to 30 degrees over the boat at a fixed speed of 7 m / s. This means that the wind in this experiment will not cause any noise. Nevertheless, we observed slight differences between runs, which are potentially due to the timing of interacting processes and delays caused by the processing of sockets in the software and operating system. A number of experiments introduced wind-related sounds into the system at two different levels. Noise was defined as a set number of wind changes per second and by the size of the bow defined by the parameters max and min wind direction specified in the simulator, expressed in degrees. Experiment two (average noise seconds) used one wind change every 30 ° and one wind change every three seconds during a single five °.

sections.heading: C. Performance Metrics
sections.text: The second measurement is the time the boat takes to complete the set course, which is a straight line distance of 550 meters. The correlation between RMSE and the time required is not as trivial as with a mobile robot, as the boat controller must balance the deviation from a straight line sufficiently to capture enough wind to move forward, against the extra time required for this maneuver. Higher boat speeds in tracksail can be achieved when the boat is travelling parallel to the wind, with the sail set to 90 degrees. However, if this is done throughout the duration, the boat would not reach its destination, so a balance between speed and course must be maintained, which is becoming increasingly important as noise is introduced into the wind direction which is variable.

sections.heading: IV. CONTROLLER SETUP
sections.text: This controller uses the same input value (error between current and desired bearings) as well as its integral over time instead of changing the error. It uses a Pgain value of 1.7 and an I-gain value of 0.01, values derived from previous experiments by Suaze and Neal. The running rate for all controllers is set at 1 Hz. This is chosen to ensure that the more sophisticated controllers can perform a full control loop. This low rate can result in lower performance than exceeding the limit values.

sections.heading: A. Hypothesis
sections.text: In our experiments, we predict that all controllers will experience a reduction in performance the more noise is released into the environment. We expect that the performance reduction shown in Type 2 systems will be less severe than that of the Type 1 controller due to their ability to deal with uncertainty. We also want to clarify the impact of the size of the FOU on the overall performance of the Type 2 controller. In our experiments, we determine whether controllers with higher FOU values will perform better than those with smaller FOUs under higher ambient noise conditions.

sections.heading: VII. FUTURE WORK
sections.text: We have shown that type 2-based systems can certainly be derived from type 1 and, under certain conditions, provide performance that goes beyond type 1 and PI-based approaches described here as an intermediate sound environment. Further work is to formalize these results and develop a method to use noise levels to generate an estimate of the FOU required for optimal performance to meet the given conditions. For example, in the above case, we would like to be able to estimate an effective FOU size based on the size and frequency of wind changes in the environment, and this method could also be applied to non-stationary approaches to observe their behavior and performance in these scenarios.
